bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, March 6, 1934

div1.p: Howard writes that his play opens tonight and discusses the changes he has made.

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, March 6, 1934

opener.dateline:
SIDNEY HOWARD
157 EAST 82ND STREET
NEW YORK
March 6th, 1934.

div1.p:
I have been on the point of writing you ever since
the troubles in Havana. Did you and your family come through
them all right and are you still all right? I hope sincerely
that you are. I have a further piece of news for you. The
play about which I talked to you in Havana will have its first
performance before the public tonight. God knows what the public
will say to it, but we shall find out tomorrow. I think I wrote
you that I changed the names of the four soldiers in the play,
though I am correcting that evil in the preface to the printed
edition, a copy of which I will send you as soon as it is off
the press. I did this partly out of consideration for you and
Kissinger -- because I could not possibly know what you were
like when you were kids and you might easily have resented any
number of things that I should have had to write for you to say --
and partly because Jernegan's widow, when she read in the papers
that the play was to be produced, began raising hell with me in
the mails. If you come to New York and if the play proves to be
worth seeing (we always have to wait for the public to tell us
that) call up Mr. Guthrie McClintic and tell him who you are or
present this letter at the box office and he will provide you with
seats. I should like to see your face when you see yourself under
the name of O'Hara and six feet, four inches tall, but if you can,
however, be reconciled to the lack of resemblance, you will enjoy
the performance of a very fine young actor. God knows what they
are going to do to us in the papers tomorrow. I have put in no
love interest, no sugar coating and no trimmings. The play is
about the experiment and nothing else and the chances are good
that it will close in a week. It is, however, much the best thing
I have written. I am going to Europe on Friday for a rest, as I
have lately opened another play here and am very tired. Please
give your wife my warmest greetings and let me hear from you when
you have time.
div1.closer: Faithfully yours, Sidney Howard. John J. Moran, Esquire.
